abstract: United States government was able to quickly identify North Korea as source of cyberattack against Sony Pictures Entertainment because of National Security Agency's careful infiltration of country's computer networks that began in 2010; previous spear fishing attacks with which attackers gained access to Sony computers were noticed but disregarded; some cybersecurity experts remain skeptical that North Korea is responsible.
lead_paragraph: Evidence gathered by software hidden by the N.S.A. to monitor North Korean activities proved critical in persuading President Obama to accuse the government of ordering the cyberattack on Sony, officials said.

byline.contributor: David E. Sanger reported from Washington, and Martin Fackler from Seoul, South Korea. Nicole Perlroth contributed reporting from San Francisco.
byline.original: By DAVID E. SANGER and MARTIN FACKLER

snippet: Evidence gathered by software hidden by the N.S.A. to monitor North Korean activities proved critical in persuading President Obama to accuse the government of ordering the cyberattack on Sony, officials said.

headline.main: N.S.A. Breached North Korean Networks Before Sony Attack, Officials Say
headline.print_headline: Tracking the Cyberattack on Sony to North Koreans
